abstract.text: Define the record types, object classes, and event types that let your app interact with Final Cut Pro.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Creating Scripting Definitions for Custom Share Destinations

inlineContent.text: As the target application of a Final Cut Pro custom share destination, your app must respond to the Apple events that Final Cut Pro sends to get information about the kind of data your users want. (See
.) Your app must also supply
scripting definitions
to define the Apple events along with their associated objects and record types. The tables in the following sections describe the definitions your app needs for its interactions with Final Cut Pro.
For an example of a complete scripting definition, see
Describes the location of the files associated with an object of a class asset. (See
Property
Type
Description
The containing folder path.
The base name for the exported output files. This name must match the asset name.
Set to
if the app requires FCPXML as the exported output.
Set to
if the app requires media as the exported output.
Describes the location of the library files associated with an asset.
Property
Type
Description
The containing folder path.
The base name for the exported output files.
Set to
if the application requires a library archive as the exported output.
Set to
if the application requires FCPXML as the exported output.
Represents an asset object that corresponds to the exported output from Final Cut Pro.
Property
Type
Description
The unique asset identifier.
The asset name.
The location of files associated with the asset.
The location of the library files associated with the asset.
The shared metadata set associated with the asset.
The options set for the asset data.

The protocol between Final Cut Pro and your app through Apple events should be agnostic to your appâ€™s object containment hierarchy. For example, the scripting definition in the Asset Management Suite Example defines an asset as a document element, but it could also define an asset as an element of a larger entity, such as a media asset database.
Your app needs only to return an object specifier with which Final Cut Pro can access a specific asset object. (See
When an asset object is not a document, handling an
Apple event to associate files to an asset might be a bit awkward. Because Cocoa Scripting handles the

Apple event, you need a custom document controller to override the behavior of Cocoa when your app opens a file and when it associates a file (based on matching the URL) with either an existing asset object or with a new asset object. You may need some customization to ensure that the files handled through the
Apple event are properly associated to the asset object.
Creates a new asset object.
Property
Type
Description
The new objectâ€™s class.
The location in which to insert the new object.*
The initial contents of the object.*
A list of object properties used to initialize the new object:
)â€”The asset name.
)â€”The metadata set associated with the asset object.
)â€”The option set used to create the asset data.
Final Cut Pro doesnâ€™t use the
and
parameters itself, but they are inherited from the respective event definitions (or
event definitions) in the standard suite. Theyâ€™re included here in case your app needs to support these parameters for other clients.

content.text: Specify an Access Group for Your App

inlineContent.text: To enable access from a sandboxed application to the objects and events in your app, your app must specify
as the access group for:
The object class for media assets
The respective element in its container

describes how to use classes and categories to create scriptable apps (referred to as Cocoa scripting) in the Cocoa application framework.

content.text: Review a Scripting Definition Example: Asset Management Suite

inlineContent.text: An app that interacts with Final Cut Pro must support the events and object classes described in the previous tables. The following code shows a complete example of a scripting definition used by an asset-management app.

code: Abstract: Asset Management suite scripting definitions

<!-- declare the namespace for using XInclude so you can include the standard suite -->
<!-- use XInclude to include the standard suite -->
<!-- specific suite(s) for the application follow... -->
<suite name="ProVideo Asset Management" code="pvam" description="Scripting terminology for Pro Video Asset Management applications.">
<property name="folder" code="asfd" type="file" description="Directory in which the asset files exist.">
<property name="base name" code="asbn" type="text" description="Base file name of the asset files.">
<property name="has media" code="ashm" type="boolean" description="Whether the asset has rendered media">
<property name="has description" code="ashd" type="boolean" description="Whether the asset has an XML description">
<property name="library folder" code="lbfd" type="file" description="Directory in which the library files exist.">
<property name="library base name" code="lbbn" type="text" description="Base file name of the library files.">
<property name="has archive" code="lbha" type="boolean" description="Whether the library has data for archive.">
<property name="has library description" code="lbhd" type="boolean" description="Whether the library has an XML description.">
<command name="make" code="corecrel" description="Create a new object.">
<parameter name="new" code="kocl" type="type" description="The class of the new object.">
<parameter name="at" code="insh" type="location specifier" optional="yes" description="The location at which to insert the object.">
<parameter name="with data" code="data" type="any" optional="yes" description="The initial contents of the object.">
<parameter name="with properties" code="prdt" type="record" optional="yes" description="The initial values for properties of the object.">
<property name="name" code="pnam" type="text" access="r" description="The name of the application.">
<property name="name" code="pnam" type="text" access="r" description="The name of the application.">
<property name="id" code="ID  " type="text" access="r" description="The unique identifier of the asset">
<property name="id" code="ID  " type="text" access="r" description="The unique identifier of the asset">
<property name="name" code="pnam" type="text" access="r" description="Its name.">
<property name="location info" code="locn" type="asset location" access="r" description="Location information of the asset.">
<property name="library info" code="lbry" type="library location" access="r" description="Location information of the containing library in the source.">
<property name="metadata" code="meta" type="user defined record" access="rw" description="Metadata associated to the asset.">
<property name="data options" code="dopt" type="user defined record" access="rw" description="Data creation options for the asset.">

abstract.text: Send media assets and timeline sequences to Final Cut Pro for editing, and receive rendered media and editing decisions in your app.

doc://com.apple.professionalvideoapplica.title: Content and Metadata Exchanges with Final Cut Pro
Review a Scripting Definition Example: Asset Management Suite

abstract.text: Receive rendered media (movies), editing descriptions for project timelines, library archives, and FCPXML for other Final Cut Pro items in your app.

doc://com.apple.professionalvideoapplica.title: Receiving Media and Data Through a Custom Share Destination

abstract.text: Tell Final Cut Pro about the kind of data your users want to receive in your app through a custom share destination.

doc://com.apple.professionalvideoapplica.title: Responding to Apple Events from Final Cut Pro

abstract.text: Support conversions between the Apple event descriptor types and Foundation object classes.

doc://com.apple.professionalvideoapplica.title: Supporting Conversions with Scripting Class Extensions

abstract.text: Exchange data with Final Cut Pro, and create effects plug-ins for Final Cut Pro and Motion.
